comment_text.mn130:1.1: Framed with the parable of the “messengers of the gods”, which are portents of mortality, this discourse expands the description of the power of clairvoyance or “divine eye” (dibbacakkhu), with a special emphasis on the descriptions of the torments of hell (niraya). This was a very popular discourse, with no fewer than six Chinese parallels and multiple references in Sanskrit literature. The Sinhala chronicle says it was taught as a primary text in Mahisamaṇḍala by Mahādeva, and in Sri Lanka by Mahinda, each time resulting in mass conversions (Mahāvaṁsa 12:29, 14:63).
comment_text.mn130:3.1: There is a set of beliefs about hell that is common to Buddhists, Hindus, and Jains. This “hell complex” includes such beliefs as: hell is long-lasting but impermanent; there are many named hells; punishments are terrible and varied; the punishment is determined by kamma; and tortures are inflicted by hell wardens. This sutta appears to be the earliest full account of this hell complex in Indian literature. Below I briefly outline the development of the hell complex in Brahmanical literature (MN 130:10.1).
comment_text.mn130:3.5: Such “messengers of the gods” appear as reminders for the dangers of mortality. Five appear here—birth, old age, sickness, punishment, and death—while AN 3.36 has three, namely old age, sickness, and death. At MN 83:4.6 we meet just one, the grey hairs of old age. In non-Buddhist texts, such messengers can also be celestial interlocutors in a more literal sense (eg. Mahābhārata 1.2.232b, 1.9.005d). | Compare the four signs that prompted Vipassī’s going forth (DN 14:2.1.1).
comment_text.mn130:10.1: The history of hell in India begins with the Rig Veda, which speaks of evil-doers facing the “erasure of the wolf”, the “downfall” (2.29.6c), the “bottomless darkness” (7.104.3) “beneath all three earths” (7.104.11), the “endless abyss” (7.104.17), the “darkness below” (10.152.4). Atharva Veda similarly speaks of the “house below” (2.14.3a), the “deepest dark” (8.2.24). It also consigns a man stingy with cattle to the nārakaṁ lokaṁ, which seems to mean “the world of the hell beings” (12.4.36c); there is an equally vague reference to a “hell being” at Śukla Yajur Veda 30.5. These seem to be the earliest uses of the word naraka in the sense of “hell”; this sense is not found in early Pali (see note on DN 12:78.2). Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42 describes the “other world” in both hellish and heavenly terms (see too Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.6.1). It depicts the hellish torments taking place in regions of the “other world” rather than as a distinct hell realm; and it does not share many details in common with later accounts. Thus far the texts are pre-Buddhist. It is not until the much later Purāṇic literature that lurid descriptions of hells, usually numbered 21 or 28, become a standard feature, along with the rest of the hell complex. Several of the places mentioned here correspond with the Purāṇic hells.
comment_text.mn130:10.3: I give a few examples of similar descriptions in the Purāṇas and the Jain Sūtrakṛtāṅga, without any attempt to be comprehensive. | The notion that one does not die despite the suffering is also found at Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.28 and Sūtrakṛtāṅga 1.5.1.16. | The lifespan of one in hell is illustrated in the story of Kokālika (SN 6.10 = AN 10.89), which is repeated at Snp 3.10 with an expanded description of the hells that bears much in common with the present discourse.
comment_text.mn130:12.1: Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.26; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23. There is a special “Upside-down hell” in Viṣṇu Purāṇa 2.63.
comment_text.mn130:16.8: The Kālasūtra hell is made of burning copper (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.14).
comment_text.mn130:18.2: Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.15 describes how the sinner runs about in pain trying to escape.
comment_text.mn130:20.3: “Needle-mouth” (sūcimukha) is one of the 28 Purāṇic hells, the destiny of scrooges, where one is stitched as cloth by a tailor (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 526.36; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23). Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.42–3 describes how sinners are devoured by sharp-toothed worms while rotting in mounds of flesh; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.17 says one is devoured by the same creatures one killed while alive.
comment_text.mn130:21.1: Burning of remnant stubble is still a widespread practice in India, and it does indeed create hellish conditions.
comment_text.mn130:22.1: The “Red Silk-Cotton Forest” (simbalivana) is one of the 28 hells (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.7; Devī Bhāgavatapurāṇa 10.21.11–28; Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.20). The red silk cotton tree (simbali, Sanskrit śālmalī, bombax ceiba) has a spiky trunk. Treading on the spikes could cause infections (Rig Veda 7.50.3). | This hell and the next reflect the miseries of struggling through thick, prickly jungles.
comment_text.mn130:23.1: The “Sword-Leaf Forest” (asipattavana; also at Snp 3.10:25.1) is another of the 28 hells. This befalls those who destroy forests (Brahmāṇḍa Purāṇa 4.2.173; Viṣṇu Purāṇa 6.2), while Agni Purāṇa 203.10 says it is for one who killed their mother, and Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.15 says it is for one who strays from the Vedas.
comment_text.mn130:24.1: The “Acid River” (khārodakā nadī) is yet another of the 28 hells (kṣārakardama, Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.8; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.30; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.21; Skanda Purāṇa 6.1.226.54).
comment_text.mn130:26.5: The “iron drink” (ayaḥpāna) is another Purāṇic hell (Agni Purāṇa 307.25–28; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.29; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23).
comment_text.mn130:29.1: This statement is found only in the Pali text, although Chinese texts are effectively similar, in that they all speak of the Buddha’s clairvoyance.

root_text.mn130:20.3: Tasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, gūthaniraye sūcimukhā pāṇā chaviṁ chindanti, chaviṁ chetvā cammaṁ chindanti, cammaṁ chetvā maṁsaṁ chindanti, maṁsaṁ chetvā nhāruṁ chindanti, nhāruṁ chetvā aṭṭhiṁ chindanti, aṭṭhiṁ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṁ khādanti.
root_text.mn130:20.4: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:21.1: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, gūthanirayassa samanantarā sahitameva mahanto kukkulanirayo.
root_text.mn130:21.3: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:22.1: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, kukkulanirayassa samanantarā sahitameva mahantaṁ simbalivanaṁ uddhaṁ yojanamuggataṁ soḷasaṅgulakaṇṭakaṁ ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ.
root_text.mn130:22.3: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:23.1: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, simbalivanassa samanantarā sahitameva mahantaṁ asipattavanaṁ.
root_text.mn130:23.3: Tassa vāteritāni pattāni patitāni hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti.
root_text.mn130:23.4: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:24.1: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, asipattavanassa samanantarā sahitameva mahatī khārodakā nadī.
root_text.mn130:24.3: So tattha anusotampi vuyhati, paṭisotampi vuyhati, anusotapaṭisotampi vuyhati.
root_text.mn130:24.4: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:25.1: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā balisena uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpetvā evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.mn130:25.5: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā tattena ayosaṅkunā mukhaṁ vivaritvā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena tattaṁ lohaguḷaṁ mukhe pakkhipanti ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ.
root_text.mn130:25.6: So tassa oṭṭhampi dahati, mukhampi dahati, kaṇṭhampi dahati, urampi dahati, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya adhobhāgā nikkhamati.
root_text.mn130:25.7: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:26.5: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā tattena ayosaṅkunā mukhaṁ vivaritvā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena tattaṁ tambalohaṁ mukhe āsiñcanti ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ.
root_text.mn130:26.6: Taṁ tassa oṭṭhampi dahati, mukhampi dahati, kaṇṭhampi dahati, urampi dahati, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya adhobhāgā nikkhamati.
root_text.mn130:26.7: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti, yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti.
root_text.mn130:27.1: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā puna mahāniraye pakkhipanti.
root_text.mn130:28.2: ‘ye kira, bho, loke pāpakāni akusalāni kammāni karonti te evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā karīyanti.
root_text.mn130:28.3: Aho vatāhaṁ manussattaṁ labheyyaṁ. Tathāgato ca loke uppajjeyya arahaṁ sammāsambuddho. Tañcāhaṁ bhagavantaṁ payirupāseyyaṁ.
root_text.mn130:28.4: So ca me bhagavā dhammaṁ deseyya. Tassa cāhaṁ bhagavato dhammaṁ ājāneyyan’ti.
root_text.mn130:29.1: Taṁ kho panāhaṁ, bhikkhave, nāññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā vadāmi, api ca yadeva sāmaṁ ñātaṁ sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ sāmaṁ viditaṁ tadevāhaṁ vadāmī”ti.
root_text.mn130:30.2: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:

translation_text.mn130:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn130:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn130:2.1: “Mendicants, suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
translation_text.mn130:2.2: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or among humans. These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the ghost realm, the animal realm, or in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
translation_text.mn130:3.1: The wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying,
translation_text.mn130:3.2: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.
translation_text.mn130:3.4: King Yama pursues, presses, and grills them about the first messenger of the gods.
translation_text.mn130:3.5: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
translation_text.mn130:4.2: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a little baby collapsed in their own urine and feces?’
translation_text.mn130:4.6: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
translation_text.mn130:4.7: “I, too, am liable to be born. I’m not exempt from rebirth. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
translation_text.mn130:4.11: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn130:4.12: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
translation_text.mn130:4.13: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
translation_text.mn130:5.1: Then King Yama grills them about the second messenger of the gods.
translation_text.mn130:5.2: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the second messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
translation_text.mn130:5.6: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings an elderly woman or a man—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy?’
translation_text.mn130:5.10: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
translation_text.mn130:5.11: “I, too, am liable to grow old. I’m not exempt from old age. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
translation_text.mn130:5.15: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn130:5.16: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
translation_text.mn130:5.17: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
translation_text.mn130:6.1: Then King Yama grills them about the third messenger of the gods.
translation_text.mn130:6.2: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the third messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
translation_text.mn130:6.6: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others?’
translation_text.mn130:6.10: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
translation_text.mn130:6.11: “I, too, am liable to become sick. I’m not exempt from sickness. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
translation_text.mn130:6.15: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn130:6.16: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
translation_text.mn130:6.17: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
translation_text.mn130:7.1: Then King Yama grills them about the fourth messenger of the gods.
translation_text.mn130:7.2: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the fourth messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
translation_text.mn130:7.6: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings when the rulers arrested a bandit, a criminal, and subjected them to various punishments—
translation_text.mn130:7.7: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘demon’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded?’
translation_text.mn130:7.11: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
translation_text.mn130:7.12: that if someone who does bad deeds receives such punishment in this very life, what must happen to them in the next; I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
translation_text.mn130:7.16: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn130:7.17: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
translation_text.mn130:7.18: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
translation_text.mn130:8.1: Then King Yama grills them about the fifth messenger of the gods.
translation_text.mn130:8.2: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the fifth messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
translation_text.mn130:8.6: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering?’
translation_text.mn130:8.10: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
translation_text.mn130:8.11: “I, too, am liable to die. I’m not exempt from death. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
translation_text.mn130:8.15: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn130:8.16: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
translation_text.mn130:8.17: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
translation_text.mn130:9.1: After grilling them about the fifth messenger of the gods, King Yama falls silent.
translation_text.mn130:10.1: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.
translation_text.mn130:10.2: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.
translation_text.mn130:10.3: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:11.1: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …
translation_text.mn130:12.1: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …
translation_text.mn130:13.1: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …
translation_text.mn130:14.1: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …
translation_text.mn130:15.1: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.
translation_text.mn130:15.3: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.
translation_text.mn130:15.4: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:16.1: The wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell.
translation_text.mn130:16.3: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,
translation_text.mn130:16.7: The ground is even made of iron,
translation_text.mn130:17.1: Now in the Great Hell, flames surge out of the walls and crash into the opposite wall: from east to west, from west to east, from north to south, from south to north, from bottom to top, from top to bottom.
translation_text.mn130:17.2: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:18.1: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the eastern gate of the Great Hell is opened.
translation_text.mn130:18.2: So they run there as fast as they can.
translation_text.mn130:18.3: And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. Such is their escape;
translation_text.mn130:18.4: but when they’ve managed to make it most of the way, the gate is slammed shut.
translation_text.mn130:18.5: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

translation_text.mn130:19.4: and they make it out that door.
translation_text.mn130:20.1: Immediately adjacent to the Great Hell is the vast Dung Hell.
translation_text.mn130:20.3: In that Dung Hell there are needle-mouthed creatures that bore through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and devour it.
translation_text.mn130:20.4: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:21.1: Immediately adjacent to the Dung Hell is the vast Hell of Burning Chaff.
translation_text.mn130:21.3: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:22.1: Immediately adjacent to the Hell of Burning Chaff is the vast Red Silk-Cotton Forest. It’s a league high, full of sixteen-inch thorns, burning, blazing, and glowing.
translation_text.mn130:22.2: And there they make them climb up and down.
translation_text.mn130:22.3: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:23.1: Immediately adjacent to the Red Silk-Cotton Forest is the vast Sword-Leaf Forest.
translation_text.mn130:23.3: There the fallen leaves blown by the wind cut their hands, feet, both hands and feet; they cut their ears, nose, both ears and nose.
translation_text.mn130:23.4: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
translation_text.mn130:24.1: Immediately adjacent to the Sword-Leaf Forest is the vast Acid River.
translation_text.mn130:24.3: There they are swept upstream, swept downstream, and swept both up and down stream.
translation_text.mn130:24.4: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

translation_text.mn130:27.1: The wardens of hell toss them back in the Great Hell.
translation_text.mn130:28.1: Once upon a time, King Yama thought:
translation_text.mn130:28.2: ‘Those who do such bad deeds in the world receive these many different punishments.
translation_text.mn130:28.3: Oh, I hope I may be reborn as a human being! And that a Realized One—a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—arises in the world! And that I may pay homage to the Buddha!
translation_text.mn130:28.4: Then the Buddha can teach me Dhamma, so that I may understand his teaching.’
translation_text.mn130:29.1: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.”
translation_text.mn130:30.1: That is what the Buddha said.
